title: Tech Alpharetta to Relocate Tech Startup Incubator
author: Business Wire
excerpt: ALPHARETTA, Ga., August 20, 2024--Tech Alpharetta, the nonprofit organization helping the City of Alpharetta to lead in tech innovation, today announced that it is relocating its tech startup…
summary:
Nonprofit to Move into Brand New Space in October 2024
ALPHARETTA, Ga., August 20, 2024--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Tech Alpharetta, the nonprofit organization helping the City of Alpharetta to lead in tech innovation, today announced that it is relocating its tech startup incubator to new space this fall at 925 North Point Parkway in Alpharetta.
Since Tech Alpharetta's incubator was established in 2015, the local tech community has grown rapidly. With that growth comes the demand for startup office space. Tech Alpharetta's new, custom designed space will double the incubator's office footprint, allowing even more young tech startups to flourish.
Tech Alpharetta will continue to provide its hot desk members and tenants with exceptional educational programming, mentoring, pitch coaching, and investor and other connections, for which its popular incubator has become known.
The new space will offer ample free parking, Wi-Fi and high-speed internet, and complimentary snacks and coffee. Additionally, there is a premier fitness facility conveniently located next door to the incubator for members who wish to join.
"We're excited to relocate this fall to our new and modern startup incubator, which will enable us to better serve the robust tech startup community here in Alpharetta and the north metro corridor," says Karen Cashion, President and CEO of Tech Alpharetta. Tech Alpharetta, which is partnered with the City of Alpharetta, has been operating its incubator since 2015 in a city-owned building on Webb Bridge Road in Alpharetta. The incubator is home to more than 50 tech startups and has been a tremendous success, producing 21 graduate companies, 1,462 new jobs for the City of Alpharetta and 2,064 total new jobs for the state of Georgia.
"Tech Alpharetta's new headquarters will allow for even more technology companies to call Alpharetta home. Since its creation in 2012, the City has been a proud supporter and contributor to Tech Alpharetta's success," notes City of Alpharetta Mayor Jim Gilvin. "We look forward to continued partnership and a shared mission for Alpharetta to remain a leading tech hub in the region."
The new incubator location is expected to open in October 2024, and Tech Alpharetta is now accepting reservations for its new tech startup offices and hot desks. Please contact Jade Rodgers, jade@techalpharetta.com, for details.
About Tech Alpharetta
Tech Alpharetta (previously the Alpharetta Technology Commission), the first organization of its kind in Georgia, was established in 2012 by the City of Alpharetta and is an independent, 501(c)(6) nonprofit organization today. The organization, whose mission is to help grow technology and innovation in Alpharetta, includes a strategic advisory board of Alpharetta's leading technology companies, and provides technology thought leadership events for area tech executives, a STEAM mentoring program for high school students, and the Tech Alpharetta Innovation Center, a flourishing tech startup incubator that is home to more than 50 tech startups.
View source version on businesswire.com: https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20240820827522/en/

title: Georgia Tech vs Virginia Tech: Hokies Close as Big Favorites vs the Yellow Jackets
author: Jackson Caudell
excerpt: Georgia Tech has been a big underdog all week leading up to the game vs Virginia Tech and with starting quarterback Haynes King ruled out for another game, the
summary:
Georgia Tech has been a big underdog all week leading up to the game vs Virginia Tech and with starting quarterback Haynes King ruled out for another game, the Yellow Jackets are going to remain big underdogs. According to the odds at Caesars Sportsbook, Georgia Tech is going to be a 10.5 point underdog today vs the Hokies.
Here is how you can watch Saturday's game.
TV: ACC Network
• Play-by-Play: Chris Cotter
• Analyst: Mark Herzlich
• Sideline Reporter: Coley Harvey
• Mobile App: ESPN
• Online: WatchESPN.com
RADIO: Georgia Tech Sports Network
• Play-by-Play: Andy Demetra
• Analyst: Andrew Gardner
• Sideline Reporter: Chris Mooneyham
• In Atlanta: 680 AM / 93.7 FM The Fan
• Across Georgia: Visit RamblinWreck.com for station affiliate list
• Satellite: SiriusXM 85
• Mobile Apps: GT Yellow Jackets, 680 The Fan, SiriusXM, TuneIn
• Online: RamblinWreck.com, 680TheFan.com
I think there are going to be a few critical areas where this game is going to be decided. The Georgia Tech offensive line vs the Virginia Tech pass rush, plus Georgia Tech's rush offense vs the Virginia Tech rush defense.
The Hokies come into this game tied for 4th in the nation in sacks, while Georgia Tech is third in the country in sacks given up, only allowing three sacks all season. Two of those sacks came on Saturday vs Notre Dame and Virginia Tech arguably has a better pass rush than the Fighting Irish. Virginia Tech defensive end Antwaun Powell-Ryland is tied for first in the nation with 11 sacks and he just had a four-sack performance vs Boston College on Thursday night. This is going to be a huge test for the Yellow Jackets and could be one of the deciding factors in the game.
The Yellow Jackets entered Saturday's game vs Notre Dame as the No. 1 rushing attack in the ACC. After that game, they are not even in the top five in the conference anymore. They dropped all the way to No. 6 after a bad performance on Saturday.
Jamal Haynes was playing his best football coming into the game, but give Notre Dame a lot of credit for not letting him get going. He finished with eight carries for 15 yards. Chad Alexander had five carries for 19 carries and Pyron finished with 13 carries for 45 yards.
Virginia Tech has the second-worst rush defense in the ACC coming into the game. Can Georgia Tech find a way to take advantage?

title: The Impact of COVID-19 on Florida's Tech Boom
author: Angela Scott-Briggs
excerpt: The COVID-19 pandemic shook the world in unprecedented ways. Every industry, country, and person felt its effects. While many regions experienced significant economic slowdowns, some, like Florida,…
summary:
The COVID-19 pandemic shook the world in unprecedented ways. Every industry, country, and person felt its effects. While many regions experienced significant economic slowdowns, some, like Florida, saw an unexpected surge in certain sectors. Florida's tech industry witnessed rapid growth during the pandemic, driven by several key factors.
Florida's Pre-Pandemic Tech Terrain
Before the pandemic, Florida had a growing tech scene. However, it wasn't considered a major player in the tech world like Silicon Valley, Seattle, or New York. The state was more known for tourism, real estate, and agriculture. Tech companies existed, but they weren't dominant.
Cities like Miami, Orlando, and Tampa were developing their tech ecosystems. Tech startups were slowly gaining traction. Still, many companies saw the state as a secondary option. The relatively low cost of living, absence of state income tax, and attractive lifestyle made Florida appealing, but the tech infrastructure wasn't fully developed.
However, everything changed with COVID-19.
The Remote Work Revolution
One of the most immediate impacts of COVID-19 was the shift to remote work. Tech companies, which had already been adopting flexible work practices, quickly moved to fully remote operations. This shift allowed employees to work from anywhere, leading many to leave expensive cities like San Francisco and New York for more affordable and desirable locations.
Florida became a top destination for these tech workers. The state's warm weather, relatively affordable housing, and lack of income tax made it an attractive option. People began to move to cities like Miami, Tampa, and Orlando in droves, fueling a tech migration that Florida had never seen before.
Moreover, this migration wasn't just limited to employees. Tech entrepreneurs and companies began to relocate as well. Startups and established firms realized they no longer needed to be tied to the high costs and congestion of traditional tech hubs. Florida became a hotspot for innovation as companies looked for a more favorable business environment.
Influx of Venture Capital
Along with the migration of tech talent came an increase in venture capital investments. Historically, Florida lagged behind states like California and New York in attracting venture capital. Investors were cautious about backing startups outside of established tech ecosystems.
But during the pandemic, investors began to see the potential in Florida's growing tech scene. The influx of talent meant more startups were being founded, and the state's business-friendly policies made it easier for them to thrive. As a result, venture capital firms started to pay more attention to Florida.
In 2020 alone, venture capital investment in Florida increased significantly. Cities like Miami began attracting national attention as a potential new tech hub. This infusion of capital further fueled the tech boom, enabling startups to scale faster and more efficiently.
The Rise of Miami as a Tech Hub
Among Florida's cities, Miami emerged as the biggest beneficiary of the pandemic-induced tech boom. The city, long known for its tourism and real estate industries, saw a dramatic transformation. Spearheaded by local leaders like Mayor Francis Suarez, Miami actively positioned itself as the next big tech hub.
Mayor Suarez's famous tweet, 'How can I help?' in response to a Silicon Valley investor's musings about moving to Miami went viral, and it marked the beginning of the city's tech renaissance. Tech founders, venture capitalists, and engineers began moving to Miami, attracted by the city's pro-business attitude and appealing lifestyle.
The city also benefited from its diverse population and proximity to Latin America, positioning it as a bridge between the U.S. and international markets. Latin American tech companies looking to expand into the U.S. found Miami to be an ideal entry point.
Moreover, Miami's tech community fostered a sense of collaboration and innovation. New co-working spaces, accelerators, and tech meetups sprang up, creating a vibrant ecosystem that rivaled more established hubs. The city's growing reputation as a tech destination attracted even more talent and investment.
Tech-Friendly Policies and Business Climate
Florida's government also played a significant role in fostering the tech boom. The state's tax policies, including the absence of state income tax, made it an attractive destination for entrepreneurs and tech workers alike. Businesses saw the potential to lower their operating costs by relocating to Florida, and individuals enjoyed the opportunity to keep more of their earnings.
Additionally, Florida's relatively relaxed approach to pandemic restrictions compared to other states allowed businesses to continue operating with fewer interruptions. While this approach sparked debate, it undeniably contributed to Florida's economic resilience and helped attract more companies looking for stability during uncertain times.
The state also made efforts to improve its tech infrastructure. Initiatives to enhance internet connectivity and support for tech education helped create a more favorable environment for tech companies. These steps, combined with the influx of talent and capital, accelerated the growth of Florida's tech sector.
Challenges of the Tech Boom
While Florida's tech boom brought numerous benefits, it also presented challenges. The rapid growth strained the state's infrastructure, particularly in cities like Miami, where housing demand skyrocketed. Home prices surged, making it difficult for some long-time residents to afford living in their own neighborhoods. The influx of new residents also put pressure on public services and transportation systems.
Additionally, while the tech sector boomed, other industries in Florida, particularly tourism, suffered significant losses due to the pandemic. This created an uneven economic recovery, with some areas thriving while others struggled.
The shift to remote work also raised concerns about the long-term sustainability of the tech boom. While many companies embraced remote work during the pandemic, some began to bring employees back to the office as restrictions eased. If remote work trends shift again, it could affect Florida's tech growth.
Long-Term Impacts on Florida's Economy
Despite these challenges, the long-term impacts of COVID-19 on Florida's tech boom are expected to be largely positive. The pandemic acted as a catalyst, accelerating trends that were already in motion. Florida's tech ecosystem is now more robust than ever, with a diverse range of startups, established companies, and investors fueling its growth.
The state's tech sector is expected to continue expanding, driven by factors like its favorable tax policies, quality of life, and growing reputation as a tech hub. Miami, in particular, is likely to remain a focal point of this growth, attracting more companies and talent from around the world.
Furthermore, the rise of Florida's tech industry could have broader implications for the state's economy. As tech companies continue to grow, they will create high-paying jobs and spur innovation in other sectors. This diversification will help Florida reduce its reliance on industries like tourism and real estate, making its economy more resilient to future disruptions.
Conclusion
The COVID-19 pandemic reshaped the global economy in profound ways, and Florida's tech boom is one of the most notable outcomes. The state, once primarily known for its tourism and real estate industries, has now emerged as a major player in the tech world. The shift to remote work, an influx of venture capital, and tech-friendly policies all contributed to this transformation. While challenges remain, the long-term outlook for Florida's tech industry is bright. The pandemic may have started the boom, but the factors driving it—talent, investment, and innovation—are likely to keep Florida's tech sector thriving for years to come.

title: What took Oklahoma State so long to start freshman QB Maealiuaki Smith?
author: Tyler Waldrep
excerpt: Only two OSU freshmen have ever thrown for more yards in their first career start and Smith's performance ranks fifth among OSU freshmen all-time.
summary:
STILLWATER — Maealiuaki answered every possible question on Saturday except one.
Why did it take so long for Oklahoma State to hand him the keys to the offense?
'It'll be able to generate a lot of talk is, why wasn't he playing two months ago?' Oklahoma State coach Mike Gundy said. 'But we would have never known two months ago. One guy (Zane Flores) broke his foot, and the other guy (Garret Rangel) broke his collarbone. Otherwise, we wouldn't even know about that today. So it's just a very unusual situation.'
Smith started the season on the scout team and didn't even begin practicing Oklahoma State's own offense until mid-October. Whether Smith could have or even should have taken meaningful practice reps earlier in the season, Gundy couldn't say following Saturday's 56-48 loss to Texas Tech.
'You're not going to take a true freshman and start giving him reps with the ones or twos when he walks right in from high school,' Gundy said.
Smith certainly did his best to shed doubt on that philosophy on Saturday, completing 26-of-36 passes for 326 yards, a touchdown, and a late-game interception that came when Smith was attempting to lead a touchdown drive with less than 20 seconds remaining in the game.
Only two OSU freshmen have ever thrown for more yards in their first career start (Wes Lunt and Aso Pogi) and his performance ranks fifth among OSU freshmen all-time. His completion percentage of 72% is the highest for any Oklahoma State quarterback in a start against a Power Four opponent since Shane Illingworth completed 73.9% against a Kansas team that finished 0-9 in 2020.
'Man, I mean, he just did so good,' OSU receiver De'Zhaun Stribling said. 'You know, you wouldn't think it was his first start, or even he's a true freshman. I mean, just the way he was out there playing was just amazing.'
Stribling caught Smith's lone touchdown pass in the end zone 14 yards downfield on a play that took a little bit to develop.
'I'm probably the last progression on that concept, and he went through the whole front side, didn't see nothing, came back to the back side, and found me open,' Stribling said. 'But just props to him staying in the pocket and make a good throw and just staying there. He's doing really great.
'He's gonna be a great player here. The way he's progressing, the way he's learning, and pay attention to all of his details and assignments, he's good.'
The play that really got his receivers' attention was Smith's 13-yard touchdown run to tie the game up halfway through the third quarter.
'That was pretty, it was pretty bold, you know,' OSU receiver Rashod Owens said when asked if any of Smith's plays surprised the senior. 'I won't say bold, but it's just, he made a great play. You know, he read the d-end perfectly, and, you know, he pulled it and ran it in for a touchdown.'
Stribling didn't mince his words so much.
'Just having the balls to run it and not be scared to get hit, that's just great,' Stribling said.
Not counting attempts when Smith dove on loose fumbles, or sacks, the freshman quarterback finished with 26 rushing yards on four carries.
Gundy felt like that was a major factor in the running game as Oklahoma State's running backs carried the ball 21 times for 200 rushing yards and four touchdowns. The group was paced by running back Ollie Gordon, who finished with a season-high 156 and three touchdowns while averaging a season-best 10.4 yards per carry. Gordon's previous best average this season was a 6.7 effort against BYU.
'We had the fear of a quarterback that could keep the ball and move around a little bit,' Gundy said. 'Defenses are going to play you a little bit different.'
Considering the BYU game also saw Oklahoma State's offense explode behind a mobile quarterback, maybe the Cowboys should consider that a requirement for future passers instead of a nice addition.
When asked that very question in the postgame, Gundy agreed with the sentiment without actually saying the quarterback in 2025 has to be a dual threat.
'When you have a quarterback, doesn't have to be a runner, but when he can maneuver himself enough to where, if the protection breaks down he can run for 6, 8 or 10 or 12 (yards), or if you need to run him in a situation and he can not get 2 or 3, he can't get 8 or 10 or 12, it helps your offense,' Gundy said. 'I mean, it becomes a numbers game.'
Gundy and both receivers praised Smith's composure throughout Saturday's game. Owens said Smith spent almost every free minute on the sidelines glued to the tablets, trying to make adjustments, which fits somewhat with Gundy's description of the freshman.
'He doesn't say much,' Gundy said. 'He's just very to himself. Good lord gave him two ears and one mouth. He uses it that way. He listens twice as much as he talks. He doesn't say a lot, but I thought he was very poised.'
Just don't mistake his quiet focus for passiveness. Once the offense huddled up, the freshman set the tone for a group that often consisted of eight-plus seniors.
'It was his offense today,' Stribling said. 'It was his offense. How he moved is how we all moved, his confidence, his attitude. He made everything happen.'

title: 2024 Timmy Awards Names Top Tech Workplaces and Leaders in North America
author: Tech in Motion
excerpt: /PRNewswire/ -- Tech in Motion has announced the North American and Community Choice Timmy Award winners in eight categories during their 2024 Timmy Awards,...
summary:
Tech in Motion recognizes this year's top employers according to tech community and industry leaders
BOSTON, Oct. 1, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- Tech in Motion has announced the North American and Community Choice Timmy Award winners in eight categories during their 2024 Timmy Awards, the 9 th edition of celebrating the best in tech workplaces. Tech in Motion, a community platform and event series with over 300,000 technologists, once again hosted the Awards program to bring together the IT community and highlight tech innovators, employers, and leaders across North America who are creating great places to work.
Hosted by award-winning author and leadership speaker John Garrett, this year's Timmy Awards gave out awards in categories including Best Tech Work Culture (both small/medium and large companies), Best Tech for Good, Best Tech Startup, Best Tech Workplace for Diversity, and Best Tech Manager, as well as two new awards for 2024, Best Tech Remote Work Culture and Technology Team of the Year.
"In such a fast-moving industry, the Timmy Awards provide us a rare opportunity to pause and celebrate the accomplishments the tech community has achieved in the past year," said Lindsay Lewis, Executive Director of Marketing at Motion Recruitment, the founders of Tech in Motion. "Every nominee and winner of the Timmys represents the top in their field, creating an environment for their tech talent to succeed both in and out of the office. We are proud to recognize all the great work these companies and leaders are doing for the industry. Our deep congratulations to all the winners of this year's awards."
The awards were judged by a panel of tech industry leaders, including presenters Chintamani Bagwe, VP at Citibank; Arylee McSweaney, Engineering Director at Etsy; Rajeep Biswas, Global VP of Industry Solutions at Neudesic; Benjamin David Novak, Partner at Morgan Lewis and Angel Investor at Delaware Crossing Investor Group; Vladyslav Podoliako, Founder and CEO at Belkins; Erin Liao, VP and Head of E2E 5G Systems at Ericsson; Tanvi Hungund, Senior Manager at Amazon Web Services; and John Rosenbaum, CIO at Motion Recruitment Partners.
The North American Timmy Award Winners include:
Leading up to the announcement, Tech in Motion also revealed the Community Choice Timmy Award winners. Decided by popular vote, over 20,000 technologists made their voices heard to determine the tech companies and leaders that would take home the coveted Timmy Awards.
The Community Choice Timmy Award Winners include:
Visit techinmotion.com to watch the 2024 Timmy Awards ceremony, RSVP for upcoming events or learn more about the Tech in Motion community.
About Tech in Motion
Tech in Motion is a North American events and community platform bringing local tech professionals together to connect, learn and innovate. What started as a passion project in 2011, by IT staffing and recruiting firm Motion Recruitment, grew into an organization of over 300,000 members across 14 chapters in North America including Boston, Chicago, Dallas, L.A., New York, Philly, San Francisco, Toronto and D.C. Visit www.techinmotion.com for more on notable speakers, sponsors and events.

title: The Impact of New York's Tech Industry on Urban Development
author: Angela Scott-Briggs
excerpt: New York City is not only a global hub for finance, fashion, and media but also a growing force in technology. Over the past few decades, the city's tech industry has flourished, shaping both its…
summary:
New York City is not only a global hub for finance, fashion, and media but also a growing force in technology. Over the past few decades, the city's tech industry has flourished, shaping both its economy and terrain. As tech giants like Google, Amazon, and Facebook expand their footprints, the city's urban development is swiftly transforming. From changing neighborhoods to influencing infrastructure, the impact of New York's tech industry on urban development is profound and far-reaching.
The Growth of New York's Tech Industry
Historically, New York was synonymous with industries like finance, real estate, and advertising. However, in recent years, its tech industry has grown at an impressive rate. The city's strategic location, access to talent, and vibrant startup culture have all contributed to this boom. New York now ranks as one of the top tech ecosystems in the world, rivaling Silicon Valley.
This fast growth is not just about startups. Major tech companies have established significant offices in the city. Google's Chelsea office, for instance, is a key example of how tech has rooted itself in the heart of Manhattan. Similarly, Amazon's expansion in Long Island City, although controversial, highlighted the city's appeal to tech firms. These companies aren't just leasing office spaces. They are also influencing the real estate market, local employment, and infrastructure.
Tech Companies and the Changing Face of Real Estate
One of the most noticeable impacts of the tech industry on New York's urban development is the transformation of real estate. As tech companies continue to grow, their demand for office space has surged. Traditionally industrial neighborhoods like Chelsea, Dumbo, and Long Island City have been transformed into tech hubs.
Chelsea, once known for its art galleries and industrial spaces, is now home to one of the largest tech office spaces in the city—Google's headquarters. This shift has brought with it a wave of development. New luxury apartments, commercial spaces, and amenities are being built to cater to tech workers. The influx of high-paying tech jobs has driven up property values, making these neighborhoods more expensive and sometimes displacing long-time residents.
In Brooklyn, the tech industry's influence is particularly evident in areas like Dumbo and Downtown Brooklyn. What was once a neighborhood of abandoned warehouses has now been revitalized. Startups, tech firms, and co-working spaces dominate the area. The increase in demand for office space has led to new high-rise developments, altering the neighborhood's skyline.
Infrastructure Developments Driven by Tech
As the tech industry grows, so does the need for improved infrastructure. The city's public transportation system, already strained by a growing population, is facing increased demand from the influx of tech workers. Neighborhoods that were once less accessible are now being developed to accommodate the new workforce.
For example, the expansion of ferry services, bike lanes, and improved subway access to areas like Long Island City and Dumbo reflects the city's efforts to support the tech industry. The demand for better internet connectivity and faster broadband speeds has also led to infrastructure upgrades. New York's tech sector thrives on innovation, and reliable internet is crucial for its success.
In response, city planners and private firms have invested heavily in expanding fiber-optic networks across the city. This investment not only benefits tech companies but also local residents, enhancing their access to high-speed internet. Moreover, tech companies themselves are investing in the city's infrastructure. Google, for example, has been involved in improving public spaces around its Chelsea offices, creating green spaces and community amenities.
Urban Revitalization and Gentrification
While the tech industry has undoubtedly brought economic benefits, it has also contributed to gentrification. Neighborhoods like Williamsburg and the Lower East Side have seen a dramatic shift in demographics, driven in part by the influx of young tech professionals.
This gentrification has resulted in increased property prices and the displacement of long-time residents. In Williamsburg, for example, new luxury condominiums have replaced old industrial buildings, pushing out local businesses and residents. The arrival of tech companies and their employees has transformed these areas, raising concerns about the long-term impact on community diversity and affordability.
However, it's not all negative. The tech industry has also brought revitalization to neighborhoods that were previously neglected. In areas like the Bronx and Queens, tech-driven developments have spurred economic growth, creating jobs and opportunities for local residents. The key challenge is ensuring that this growth is inclusive and that the benefits of urban development are shared by all.
Tech's Influence on the Future of Workspaces
Another significant impact of New York's tech industry on urban development is the changing nature of workspaces. Traditional office buildings are being redesigned to accommodate the needs of tech companies. Open floor plans, flexible workspaces, and communal areas are becoming the norm, reflecting the tech industry's emphasis on collaboration and innovation.
The rise of co-working spaces is also a direct result of the tech boom. Companies like WeWork, which originated in New York, have revolutionized the way people work. These spaces cater to startups, freelancers, and remote workers, providing flexible office solutions in prime locations. As a result, traditional office leasing models are being challenged, and developers are now focusing on creating more adaptable workspaces.
The Role of Technology in Sustainable Urban Development
The tech industry is also playing a pivotal role in driving sustainable urban development. Tech companies are increasingly aware of their environmental impact and are investing in green buildings and eco-friendly technologies. Google's New York office, for example, has been designed with sustainability in mind, featuring energy-efficient systems and promoting green practices.
Moreover, the rise of smart city technologies, driven by tech firms, is reshaping how cities like New York are planned and managed. From smart traffic lights to energy-efficient buildings, technology is being used to create more sustainable and livable urban environments. The tech industry's push for innovation is helping the city address challenges like congestion, pollution, and energy consumption.
Conclusion
The impact of New York's tech industry on urban development is undeniable. As tech companies continue to expand, their influence on real estate, infrastructure, and community development will only grow. While the economic benefits are clear, the city must also address the challenges of gentrification and displacement to ensure that urban development is inclusive.
New York's tech industry has the potential to shape a more sustainable and innovative urban future. However, achieving this requires collaboration between the public and private sectors. By balancing growth with inclusivity, New York can continue to thrive as a leading tech hub while ensuring that its development benefits all residents. The intersection of tech and urban development offers exciting possibilities for the city's future.

title: Future of Tech Talent in Australia: Insights from the TCA's Partner Forum
author: Harshini Chakka
excerpt: The future of tech talent in Australia is shaping up to be dynamic and promising. The Tech Council of Australia (TCA) is at the forefront of this movement. Thro
summary:
The future of tech talent in Australia is shaping up to be dynamic and promising. The Tech Council of Australia (TCA) is at the forefront of this movement. Through initiatives like its Partner Forum, the TCA is addressing the nation's growing tech workforce shortage. With industries from retail to mining embracing digital transformation, the demand for skilled tech workers is higher than ever.
But how is Australia tackling this challenge? The answer lies in collaboration, innovation, and strategic programs.
Why Tech Talent Matters to Australia
Tech talent is not just essential for technology companies—it's a necessity across the entire Australian economy. Around 62% of the country's tech workers are employed outside of traditional tech industries. Companies in banking, mining, and retail now rely heavily on tech solutions to modernize operations and improve efficiency.
The Tech Council of Australia understands this shift. It's pushing for greater technology adoption in every sector. This doesn't only benefit tech companies but also helps non-tech organizations develop their own tech capabilities. The Partner Forum is at the heart of this initiative, bringing together industry leaders to foster innovation and develop new pipelines for tech talent.
The Role of the TCA's Partner Forum
The Tech Council of Australia's Partner Forum is a platform for tackling key industry challenges. Rapid advancements in AI and increasing cybersecurity threats highlight the need for skilled tech workers. To address this, the Partner Forum unites large organizations such as Commonwealth Bank and NBN Co. Together, they discuss strategies for building tech talent pipelines and promoting technology adoption.
Richard White, CEO of WiseTech, believes that tech talent isn't limited to tech companies. Many workers are employed in sectors like finance and logistics, supporting the broader economy. The Partner Forum acts as a bridge, connecting industries and helping them shape a stronger future for Australia's tech talent.
How Technology Companies Develop Tech Talent
Technology companies are not just employing tech talent—they are nurturing it. WiseTech, one of the major players, has launched the Earn and Learn Program. This initiative provides students with real-world experience in software engineering while they complete their degrees. The goal is to prepare students for a career in tech by giving them hands-on experience.
Another innovative project is the Virtual Work Experience Program. It has benefited over 2,000 learners in fields like data science, software engineering, and cybersecurity. These programs are part of the TCA's broader strategy to close the skills gap and develop a robust tech workforce.
Technology Adoption Beyond Tech Companies
Tech adoption in Australia is not limited to tech firms. Various industries, from healthcare to agriculture, are embracing technology to enhance their operations. The TCA sees this as a critical trend for the country's economic growth. By joining the Partner Forum, companies across different sectors can access resources and share insights on building their tech capabilities.
The Tech Council of Australia believes that technology should not only drive business growth but also contribute to workforce development. The Partner Forum provides a space for companies to collaborate, shape policies, and invest in technology adoption.
Embracing Diversity in the Tech Workforce
The tech industry in Australia has a diversity problem. Women represent only 28% of the IT workforce. The Tech Council of Australia recognizes this issue and is working to create a more inclusive environment. Programs focused on empowering underrepresented groups and fostering tech skills are critical to closing the gender gap.
The closure of initiatives like the Boosting Female Founders Program is a setback, but the TCA remains committed to supporting diversity and inclusion in tech. An inclusive workforce is not just beneficial for companies—it's essential for innovation and growth.
The Australian Government's Role
The Australian government has set a target of creating 1.2 million tech jobs by 2030. The Department of Industry, Science and Resources is actively monitoring this progress. As of May 2023, the number of tech jobs in the country was at 930,000. The TCA estimates that AI alone will create an additional 200,000 jobs by the end of the decade.
But to reach these goals, Australia needs to address its skills shortage. The Tech Council of Australia is calling for more investment in education and reskilling initiatives. This requires a coordinated effort from the government, industries, and educational institutions.
Building a Future-Ready Tech Workforce
The future of tech talent in Australia relies on collaboration. The Tech Council of Australia's Partner Forum is encouraging stakeholders to come together, innovate, and build a stronger tech workforce. Technology companies play a crucial role in talent development, but the entire ecosystem—government, industries, and communities—must work together to achieve sustainable growth.
Technology adoption is spreading across industries, creating new opportunities for tech professionals. This trend will continue to redefine the workforce as businesses seek to modernize and enhance their operations.
Conclusion
The future of tech talent in Australia is filled with both challenges and opportunities. The Tech Council of Australia is making strides to ensure that the nation is prepared for the future. Through its Partner Forum, the TCA is pushing for increased technology adoption, workforce innovation, and a more inclusive tech environment.
With continued support from the government and the collaboration of industries, Australia can achieve its ambitious goal of creating 1.2 million tech jobs by 2030. By nurturing the next generation of tech professionals and embracing diversity, Australia's tech sector is poised for a bright and sustainable future.
The journey ahead is not easy, but with a shared vision and commitment, the Tech Council of Australia and its Partner Forum will play a pivotal role in shaping the nation's tech talent landscape.

title: Georgia Tech vs Virginia Tech: Hokies Close as Big Favorites vs the Yellow Jackets
author: Jackson Caudell
excerpt: Georgia Tech has been a big underdog all week leading up to the game vs Virginia Tech and with starting quarterback Haynes King ruled out for another game, the
summary:
Georgia Tech has been a big underdog all week leading up to the game vs Virginia Tech and with starting quarterback Haynes King ruled out for another game, the Yellow Jackets are going to remain big underdogs. According to the odds at Caesars Sportsbook, Georgia Tech is going to be a 10.5 point underdog today vs the Hokies.
Here is how you can watch Saturday's game.
TV: ACC Network
• Play-by-Play: Chris Cotter
• Analyst: Mark Herzlich
• Sideline Reporter: Coley Harvey
• Mobile App: ESPN
• Online: WatchESPN.com
RADIO: Georgia Tech Sports Network
• Play-by-Play: Andy Demetra
• Analyst: Andrew Gardner
• Sideline Reporter: Chris Mooneyham
• In Atlanta: 680 AM / 93.7 FM The Fan
• Across Georgia: Visit RamblinWreck.com for station affiliate list
• Satellite: SiriusXM 85
• Mobile Apps: GT Yellow Jackets, 680 The Fan, SiriusXM, TuneIn
• Online: RamblinWreck.com, 680TheFan.com
I think there are going to be a few critical areas where this game is going to be decided. The Georgia Tech offensive line vs the Virginia Tech pass rush, plus Georgia Tech's rush offense vs the Virginia Tech rush defense.
The Hokies come into this game tied for 4th in the nation in sacks, while Georgia Tech is third in the country in sacks given up, only allowing three sacks all season. Two of those sacks came on Saturday vs Notre Dame and Virginia Tech arguably has a better pass rush than the Fighting Irish. Virginia Tech defensive end Antwaun Powell-Ryland is tied for first in the nation with 11 sacks and he just had a four-sack performance vs Boston College on Thursday night. This is going to be a huge test for the Yellow Jackets and could be one of the deciding factors in the game.
The Yellow Jackets entered Saturday's game vs Notre Dame as the No. 1 rushing attack in the ACC. After that game, they are not even in the top five in the conference anymore. They dropped all the way to No. 6 after a bad performance on Saturday.
Jamal Haynes was playing his best football coming into the game, but give Notre Dame a lot of credit for not letting him get going. He finished with eight carries for 15 yards. Chad Alexander had five carries for 19 carries and Pyron finished with 13 carries for 45 yards.
Virginia Tech has the second-worst rush defense in the ACC coming into the game. Can Georgia Tech find a way to take advantage?

title: How Florida's Tech Industry is Competing with Silicon Valley and New York
author: Angela Scott-Briggs
excerpt: The tech industry is thriving across the United States, with certain cities gaining more prominence than others. For years, Silicon Valley and New York have been synonymous with innovation,…
summary:
The tech industry is thriving across the United States, with certain cities gaining more prominence than others. For years, Silicon Valley and New York have been synonymous with innovation, entrepreneurship, and technological advancements. However, a new contender is rising—Florida. Traditionally known for its tourism and real estate, the Sunshine State is now emerging as a tech hub, attracting entrepreneurs, investors, and skilled professionals. Florida's tech industry is growing at a rapid pace, and it's giving the established giants like Silicon Valley and New York some serious competition.
A Favorable Business Environment
One of the primary reasons Florida is becoming an attractive destination for tech companies is its favorable business environment. Unlike New York and California, Florida boasts a low-tax structure, with no state income tax, which is a significant draw for entrepreneurs and investors alike. This tax advantage means more disposable income for businesses and employees, which can be reinvested in growth, innovation, and attracting talent.
Furthermore, the cost of living in Florida is relatively lower than in the established tech hubs. Rent, housing, and operational costs are more affordable, allowing startups and tech firms to stretch their budgets further. This financial flexibility has made Florida particularly appealing for small to medium-sized tech enterprises that might struggle with the high expenses in Silicon Valley or New York.
Emerging Tech Cities
While Miami is leading the charge, cities like Orlando, Tampa, and Jacksonville are also becoming tech hubs in their own right. Miami, often dubbed the 'next Silicon Valley,' has become a hotspot for venture capital and tech startups. With its international connections, particularly with Latin America, Miami serves as a gateway for tech companies looking to expand globally. The city's vibrant culture and growing reputation as a tech hub have drawn in entrepreneurs from across the world.
Orlando, traditionally known for its theme parks, is now gaining recognition for its tech scene. The presence of major universities and research institutions has fostered innovation in fields like aerospace, simulation technology, and gaming. Tampa and Jacksonville are also seeing rapid growth in sectors such as cybersecurity, fintech, and health tech. This diversification across different cities is allowing Florida to build a robust, decentralized tech ecosystem that can compete with the concentrated tech scenes of Silicon Valley and New York.
Talent Attraction and Retention
Talent is the lifeblood of the tech industry, and one of the critical factors in Florida's rise as a tech hub is its ability to attract and retain skilled professionals. In recent years, Florida has seen an influx of talent from both coasts. Many tech professionals are leaving Silicon Valley and New York due to the high cost of living and seeking out more affordable and sustainable lifestyles in Florida.
Moreover, the COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the trend of remote work, allowing tech workers to relocate without leaving their jobs. Florida's sunny weather, vibrant lifestyle, and lower living costs make it an ideal destination for tech professionals looking for a change in environment. The state's universities, including the University of Florida, Florida State University, and the University of Miami, are also churning out a new generation of tech-savvy graduates, ensuring a steady pipeline of local talent.
Investment and Venture Capital
For any tech ecosystem to thrive, access to funding is crucial. While Silicon Valley and New York have long dominated the venture capital space, Florida is catching up. Over the past few years, there has been a significant increase in venture capital investment in Florida-based tech startups. Major venture capital firms, as well as angel investors, are recognizing Florida's potential and are pouring money into the state's growing tech scene.
Miami, in particular, has seen a surge in investment activity, with numerous high-profile tech companies setting up shop in the city. This influx of capital is fueling innovation, allowing startups to scale rapidly and compete on a national and global level. The increase in investment has also attracted more entrepreneurs to Florida, further strengthening its position as a viable alternative to Silicon Valley and New York.
Supportive Infrastructure
A tech hub cannot thrive without the necessary infrastructure to support it. Florida has been making strides in building the infrastructure needed to sustain its growing tech industry. The state is home to several incubators, accelerators, and co-working spaces that foster innovation and collaboration among startups. These spaces provide entrepreneurs with access to mentorship, networking opportunities, and resources that are vital for business growth.
Additionally, Florida's transportation network, including major international airports, ports, and highways, makes it an ideal location for tech companies that need to operate globally. Miami International Airport, for example, is one of the busiest international hubs in the U.S., providing easy access to Latin America and other international markets. This connectivity is a significant advantage for tech companies looking to expand their reach beyond the U.S.
A Growing Tech Ecosystem
Florida's tech ecosystem is growing in diversity, with a wide range of sectors represented. From fintech and health tech to aerospace and cybersecurity, Florida's tech industry is far from a one-trick pony. This diversity is helping to attract different types of businesses and investors, creating a dynamic and resilient tech scene.
The state's growing tech ecosystem is also supported by a collaborative business community. Organizations like the Florida High Tech Corridor, eMerge Americas, and Techstars have been instrumental in fostering connections between startups, investors, and industry leaders. These organizations provide valuable resources, mentorship, and networking opportunities that help tech companies thrive.
Moreover, the presence of established tech companies in the state is helping to solidify Florida's reputation as a tech hub. Major corporations like Magic Leap, Citrix, and Chewy have set up headquarters or significant operations in Florida, providing a strong foundation for the state's tech ecosystem to grow.
Government Support and Incentives
Florida's government has been proactive in supporting the growth of the tech industry. The state offers various incentives for businesses, including tax credits, grants, and workforce training programs. These incentives have been designed to attract tech companies and encourage them to establish operations in Florida.
In addition to financial incentives, the state has been investing in education and workforce development to ensure that there is a steady supply of skilled tech workers. Florida's universities and technical schools are partnering with tech companies to develop curricula that align with the needs of the industry. This collaboration between the public and private sectors is helping to build a strong talent pipeline and ensuring that Florida remains competitive in the tech space.
Competing with the Giants
While Silicon Valley and New York have the advantage of being established tech hubs with a long history of innovation, Florida is proving that it has what it takes to compete. The state's favorable business environment, growing talent pool, increasing investment, and supportive infrastructure are all contributing to its rise as a tech hub.
One area where Florida is particularly competitive is quality of life. While tech professionals in Silicon Valley and New York may enjoy high salaries, they often have to contend with sky-high living costs and a fast-paced, stressful lifestyle. In contrast, Florida offers a more balanced and affordable way of life, without sacrificing career opportunities. This quality of life advantage is attracting more and more tech workers and entrepreneurs to the Sunshine State, helping to fuel its tech industry's growth.
Conclusion
Florida's tech industry is on the rise, and it's becoming a serious contender in the national tech landscape. With a favorable business environment, growing investment, and a supportive ecosystem, Florida is proving that it can compete with established tech hubs like Silicon Valley and New York. As more talent and capital flow into the state, Florida's tech scene is only expected to grow stronger in the coming years. For entrepreneurs, investors, and tech professionals looking for the next big thing, Florida is certainly a place to watch.

title: The Role of Texas's Tech Industry in Job Creation
author: Angela Scott-Briggs
excerpt: Texas, known for its vast space, rich cultural history, and economic might, has emerged as a technological powerhouse in recent years. As the tech industry continues to transform, it is not only…
summary:
Texas, known for its vast space, rich cultural history, and economic might, has emerged as a technological powerhouse in recent years. As the tech industry continues to transform, it is not only transforming business landscapes but also driving significant job creation across the state. From Austin's Silicon Hills to Dallas's robust tech scene, Texas has established itself as a key player in the national and global tech ecosystem.
A Thriving Tech Hub: Texas's Position in the U.S. Tech Market
Texas's tech industry ranks among the largest in the United States, with the state consistently attracting major players like Dell, Texas Instruments, Apple, Oracle, and Google. The cities of Austin, Dallas, Houston, and San Antonio have emerged as tech hubs, each contributing to the expansion of the tech workforce. The state's pro-business climate, relatively affordable cost of living, and its strong infrastructure support make it an appealing destination for tech companies and professionals alike.
In addition to well-established corporations, Texas has become a fertile ground for startups and emerging tech firms. The surge in venture capital investment, incubators, and innovation labs has enabled smaller companies to thrive, thereby contributing to the rapid creation of new job opportunities across a variety of tech subfields. These include software development, artificial intelligence, cybersecurity, and financial technology, to name a few.
Major Tech Companies Driving Employment
Several major tech companies have set up or expanded their operations in Texas, leading to a tech-driven employment boom. Apple, for instance, has invested heavily in expanding its presence in Austin with its sprawling campus, which is projected to employ thousands of workers. Similarly, Oracle's relocation of its headquarters to Austin further cemented the city's standing as a tech epicenter, bringing with it new jobs in software development, engineering, and IT services.
Dallas, with companies like Texas Instruments and AT&T, also plays a vital role in shaping the local job market. Texas Instruments, a global leader in semiconductor manufacturing, has long been a cornerstone of Dallas's economy, employing tens of thousands of workers. As Texas Instruments continues to innovate in chip manufacturing, the company also drives demand for skilled talent, contributing to job growth in both high-tech manufacturing and research.
Furthermore, Houston, known for its oil and energy sector, has embraced technological innovation. Companies like Hewlett Packard Enterprise have made significant investments in Houston's tech sector, particularly in cloud computing and enterprise software solutions, leading to job creation in various IT and development roles. Overall, Texas's tech industry is not limited to a single city, but spreads across its major metropolitan areas, each contributing to the state's employment growth.
Startups and Emerging Tech: A Key Contributor to Job Growth
While major tech companies play a crucial role in Texas's job creation, startups and emerging tech firms also make a significant impact. The state's robust startup ecosystem has flourished in cities like Austin, with the city's favorable business environment and its appeal to young entrepreneurs creating a thriving scene for new ventures. The growing number of venture capital firms and startup accelerators in the state has made Texas an attractive destination for aspiring tech entrepreneurs.
Startups in sectors like artificial intelligence, blockchain, health tech, and fintech are creating new jobs that not only drive the economy but also introduce fresh talent into the workforce. The diverse range of roles in startups—from software engineers and product developers to marketing professionals and data scientists—enables tech workers to find a variety of opportunities that align with their skills and career aspirations. In this way, Texas's startup ecosystem is fueling innovation while also expanding the range of job opportunities available to its tech workforce.
The Ripple Effect: Indirect Job Creation in Texas's Tech Ecosystem
The expansion of the tech industry in Texas has had a ripple effect on indirect job creation. As tech companies continue to grow, the demand for complementary services increases, creating employment opportunities in various sectors such as real estate, marketing, and transportation. Real estate, in particular, has benefited from the influx of tech workers and companies, as cities like Austin and Dallas have seen an increased demand for office space, housing, and related infrastructure.
Additionally, local service industries—such as retail, food, and hospitality—have expanded as a result of the tech boom, with more workers moving into the region. This growth in service-sector employment helps sustain the broader economy, creating a multiplier effect that benefits a wide range of industries beyond the direct tech workforce.
Education and Workforce Development: Preparing for Future Tech Jobs
To sustain its growth as a tech hub and to meet the rising demand for skilled workers, Texas has invested heavily in education and workforce development. Many universities and community colleges across the state have introduced tech-focused degree programs, partnerships with local tech firms, and training initiatives designed to prepare students for careers in the tech industry. Schools like the University of Texas at Austin and Texas A&M University have long been recognized for their strong computer science, engineering, and business programs, producing a steady stream of graduates who are ready to enter the tech workforce.
Workforce development programs such as coding boot camps and apprenticeship programs are also gaining traction in Texas, providing accessible pathways to tech careers for individuals from diverse backgrounds. These programs are designed to equip participants with the technical skills required by companies in fields like software development, cybersecurity, and data analysis, helping to bridge the talent gap and ensure that Texas has a highly skilled workforce capable of supporting its growing tech sector.
Remote Work: Expanding Opportunities for Tech Workers
The rise of remote work, accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic, has further expanded job opportunities in Texas's tech industry. Many tech companies have adopted hybrid or fully remote work models, allowing them to recruit talent from across the state, the country, and even internationally. This flexibility has made Texas even more attractive to tech workers who value the opportunity to work for top-tier companies while enjoying the state's lower cost of living and high quality of life.
Remote work has also enabled smaller cities and rural areas in Texas to benefit from the tech job boom. Tech workers no longer need to be concentrated in urban centers like Austin and Dallas; instead, they can work remotely from smaller towns, contributing to local economies and helping to distribute the economic benefits of the tech sector more widely across the state.
Conclusion
Texas's tech industry has proven to be a driving force in job creation, with its combination of major corporations, a thriving startup ecosystem, and a pro-business environment creating a fertile ground for innovation and employment. The state's ability to attract top tech talent and its commitment to education and workforce development position it well for continued growth in the tech sector. As tech companies expand and diversify, the impact of the tech industry on Texas's job market will only grow stronger, benefiting a wide range of industries and contributing to the state's overall economic prosperity. Whether through direct employment in tech roles or the ripple effects in related industries, Texas's tech boom is a key contributor to job creation and an essential pillar of the state's economic future.

title: EEOC Research Finds Unequal Opportunity in the High Tech Sector and Workforce
excerpt: WASHINGTON – The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) today released a report, 'High Tech, Low Inclusion: Diversity in the High Tech...
summary:
WASHINGTON – The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) today released a report, ' High Tech, Low Inclusion: Diversity in the High Tech Workforce and Sector from 2014 - 2022 ' which highlights demographic disparities for workers in 56 science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) occupations and the industries employing them.
The report assesses the current state of diversity in the high tech workforce and those employed in the high tech sector. It also discusses the most common discrimination charges filed by high tech sector workers with the EEOC, building on previous reports from 2016 and 2017 by the EEOC and the Government Accountability Office (GAO), respectively.
The EEOC report released today acknowledges that employers have made limited progress toward including qualified workers of all backgrounds in the high tech sector and high tech workforce but concludes that significant barriers still remain to equal employment opportunity in high tech. The magnitude of the underrepresentation for some demographic groups, particularly for women and Black workers, combined with research and the EEOC's experience enforcing anti-discrimination laws, suggest that discrimination likely contributes to the relatively low employment of women, Black workers, Hispanic workers, and older workers in high tech.
'Sixty years after passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, there is a high degree of underrepresentation and a disturbing lack of career advancement for female, Black, and Hispanic workers in the high tech workforce, despite the recent period of growth in high tech occupations. America's high tech sector, which leads the world in crafting technologies of the future, should not have a workforce that looks like the past,' said EEOC Chair Charlotte A. Burrows. 'These data raise serious questions that deserve serious answers.'
Burrows said, 'At the Commission, we will work to identify instances in which discrimination has contributed to these disparities. It is important for high tech employers to self-assess and address any discriminatory barriers limiting employment opportunities and to implement proactive policies to increase inclusion. Everyone deserves access to these high tech opportunities, which often provide competitive pay, benefits, job security, and stability.'
Findings from the report include:
Female, Black, and Hispanic workers remained substantially underrepresented in the high tech workforce and sector. Between 2005 and 2022 there was very little change in the representation of Black workers and virtually no change in the representation of female workers occurred in the high tech workforce. (see Section III)
Black, Hispanic and Asian workers were underrepresented in managerial positions compared to their participation in the high tech workforce overall. (see Section V)
While women are nearly half of the total U.S. workforce, they were just 22.6% of the high tech workforce in all industries, and only 4% of the high tech workforce in the high tech sector. (see Section V, Tables 11 and 12)
The high tech workforce is generally younger than the total U.S. workforce; 40.8% of the high tech workforce are ages 25 to 39, but only 33.1% of the overall workforce. Workers over age 40 in the high tech workforce lost ground between 2014 and 2022, declining from 55.9% to 52.1%. (see Section V, Table 9)
Charges of discrimination filed with the EEOC in the tech sector were more likely to involve discrimination based on age, pay, and/or genetic information than those filed in other sectors. (see Section VII)
Given its findings, the report recommends that high tech companies proactively examine barriers limiting employment for women, older workers, Black workers, and Hispanic workers.

title: College Football Bowl Projections: Where is Georgia Tech Projected to Play After Their Loss to Notre Dame?
author: Jackson Caudell
excerpt: Georgia Tech is coming off of a loss to Notre Dame, but the Yellow Jackets are only one win away from making their second consecutive bowl game under head coach
summary:
Georgia Tech is coming off of a loss to Notre Dame, but the Yellow Jackets are only one win away from making their second consecutive bowl game under head coach Brent Key. It will not be easy to get there however, as their final four games are tough. Georgia Tech travels to Virginia Tech this Saturday, then hosts No. 6 Miami and NC State, and finishes up with a trip to No. 2 Georgia. It is not a given that Georgia Tech is going to get to a bowl game.
All of the major bowl projections still have Georiga Tech in the postseason.
ESPN's Kyle Bonagura has Georgia Tech going to Boston to play in the Fenway Bowl and their opponent is Memphis. The Tigers are 6-1 this season and the only loss they have suffered so far this year is to Navy, who is currently undefeated. Like Georgia Tech, Memphis has a win vs Florida State. This would be the fourth-ever meeting between the programs and Georgia Tech leads the all-time series. It would be their first meeting since 1982.
ESPN's Mark Schlabach has Georgia Tech going to another location. He has the Yellow Jackets going to El Paso to play in the Sun Bowl and their opponent is Oregon State. The Beavers are currently 4-3 this season and still have their work cut out for them as far as making a bowl game goes. Georgia Tech and Oregon State have never played each other before.
Over at 247Sports, Brad Crawford has Georgia Tech projected to play in the Military Bowl vs Navy and that would be a very interesting matchup. Navy is currently undefeated and hoping to make the College Football Playoff as the Group of Five Champion and they face Notre Dame this weekend. This would be the 26th all-time meeting between the two programs, with Georgia Tech leading the series 16-9. They have not faced each other since 2001.
At the Action Network, Brett McMurphy has a very interesting matchup for the Yellow Jackets. He has Georgia Tech going back to Tampa Bay to play in the Gasparilla Bowl, but this time to face the Florida Gators. After getting blown out by Miami to start the season, Florida has rebounded a little bit and now sits at 4-3. They have a very tough stretch to end the season, but they are playing better than they were at the beginning of the season. Georgia Tech has a big lead in the all-time series vs the Gators, leading it 23-9. It has been over 40 years since they have played though with the last meeting coming in 1981.
With the season winding down, Georgia Tech has four more opportunities to get to another bowl game.

Georgia Tech Football: PFF Grades and Snap Counts vs Notre Dame
Georgia Tech Football: Key Takeaways From The Yellow Jackets 31-13 Loss to Notre Dame

title: Everything you need to know about Georgia Tech at Virginia Tech
author: Chad Bishop
excerpt: Georgia Tech concludes October with a trip to Blacksburg, Virginia, where the Hokies of Virginia Tech await inside Lane Stadium.
summary:
Georgia Tech concludes October with a trip to Blacksburg, Virginia, where the Hokies of Virginia Tech await inside Lane Stadium.
The Yellow Jackets (5-3, 3-2 ACC) could view Saturday's contest as a rubber match of sorts: A win over the Hokies would give Tech six wins before November for the first time since 2014 and make Tech 12-1 under coach Brent Key following a loss. A defeat would give Tech its first losing streak since October 2022 and put it in grave danger of falling short of bowl eligibility, with only three games remaining after the weekend.
On paper, Tech has a favorable matchup on offense if it can rediscover its ground game. Virginia Tech has one of the worst rushing defenses in the country at 170.3 yards allowed per game. But the Hokies do have the second-best pass defense in the ACC, and that could be a concern for the Jackets, given that starting quarterback Haynes King likely will miss a second consecutive game with an injury.

title: Sterling tech career fair debuts in Africa
author: Etop Ekanem
excerpt: The maiden edition of the Sterling Tech Career Fair was held in Africa with Lagos as host recently, following six successful years in the UK and Canada.
summary:
The maiden edition of the Sterling Tech Career Fair was held in Africa with Lagos as host recently, following six successful years in the UK and Canada.
The two-day fair, convened by Mrs. Modupe Yusuf, Founder of Sterling Tech Solution UK, in collaboration with Rhythm of Honour Nigeria, is said to bridge the gap in tech talent acquisition.
Themed, 'Positioning and Repositioning for Tech Career,' the fair emphasized the importance of relevant tech skills in unlocking career opportunities for African youths.
The convener, Yusuf, advocated for African youths to leverage the tech space through education, skills development programmes, and fostering a creative environment.
She urged tech companies in Africa to provide internship opportunities for young talent, promoting diversity and inclusion, adding that the ultimate goal is to co-create a tech skills development platform in Africa.
The convener further stated that the tech career fair offers a platform for networking with industry experts, tech skills development and training, career opportunities and internships, innovation and entrepreneurship.
One of the speakers, Mrs. Ayodele Lanre-Yusuf, Founder, Rhythm of Honour, advised youths to develop employable skills and not rely on just their university degrees.
She said: 'Skills are what set you apart. We want to empower Africans to take advantage of the tech space and break social norms that limit their potential.
'Our youths must learn how to position and reposition themselves for tech career success.'
The event had different sessions with several experts who spoke and shared their entrepreneurship and tech industry experience.
Some of the speakers at the event included Mrs. Ayodele Lanre-Yusuf, Mr. ⁠Wale Olaisade, Mrs. Hannatu Adegboyega, Tosin Obembe, Ayotomi Faleyimu, ⁠Chimezie Onwuma, Funke Alomoluwa, Oluwatosin Aroloye among others.

title: The Role of Florida's Business-Friendly Environment in Attracting Tech Companies
author: Angela Scott-Briggs
excerpt: Florida has long been known for its sun, beaches, and vibrant tourism industry. However, in recent years, it has emerged as a hotspot for tech companies seeking a more favorable business environment.…
summary:
Florida has long been known for its sun, beaches, and vibrant tourism industry. However, in recent years, it has emerged as a hotspot for tech companies seeking a more favorable business environment. From tax incentives to a highly skilled workforce, Florida's business-friendly policies are reshaping its economy. The state is now being recognized as a growing tech hub, rivaling traditional innovation centers like Silicon Valley.
The Appeal of Florida's Tax-Friendly Climate
One of the key reasons tech companies are flocking to Florida is its tax structure. Florida is one of the few states in the U.S. without a personal income tax. This feature is highly attractive to both businesses and employees. For tech entrepreneurs and employees, this means more take-home pay. It also allows companies to offer competitive salaries without the burden of excessive taxation.
For businesses, Florida offers corporate tax rates that are lower than many other states. This is particularly beneficial for tech startups and small companies, where managing overhead is critical to survival. Furthermore, the state offers a variety of tax credits and exemptions aimed at fostering innovation. These include incentives for research and development, which are particularly appealing to tech companies focused on innovation. The combination of these financial benefits makes Florida a prime location for companies looking to reduce costs while still having access to a dynamic market.
Strategic Location and Infrastructure
Florida's geographic location also plays a significant role in its appeal to tech companies. With its proximity to Latin America and Europe, Florida serves as a gateway for international business. Many tech companies with global ambitions are drawn to the state for its strategic access to these markets.
In addition to its strategic location, Florida boasts a robust infrastructure that supports business growth. The state has invested heavily in its transportation network, including airports, seaports, and highways, making it easier for businesses to connect with clients and partners around the world. This level of connectivity is especially important for tech companies involved in global commerce, logistics, or international services.
Additionally, Florida's telecommunications infrastructure is state-of-the-art, providing tech companies with reliable and fast internet, cloud services, and data storage capabilities. This is crucial for industries like fintech, cybersecurity, and software development that rely heavily on digital infrastructure. The combination of these logistical and digital advantages ensures that companies have the resources they need to succeed.
A Supportive Regulatory Environment
Florida's regulatory environment is another factor that contributes to its attractiveness to tech companies. The state government has made efforts to reduce bureaucratic hurdles that often stifle business growth in other regions. Florida is known for having fewer regulations compared to other states, making it easier for businesses to operate. For tech companies, which often need flexibility to innovate and grow, this lighter regulatory touch is highly appealing.
The state also supports a fast-track permitting process for businesses, enabling companies to set up operations quickly. This is especially beneficial for tech companies that need to be agile and responsive to market changes. In addition, Florida offers strong protections for intellectual property rights, a critical concern for tech companies whose products and services often revolve around proprietary technology. The ease of doing business, combined with strong legal protections, makes Florida a compelling destination for tech firms.
A Growing Tech Talent Pool
While the financial and regulatory environment is critical, access to talent is equally important for tech companies. Florida has recognized this and has invested in education and workforce development programs aimed at creating a skilled labor pool for the tech industry. The state is home to several top-tier universities, including the University of Florida, Florida State University, and the University of Miami, which have strong engineering and computer science programs.
These universities are producing a steady stream of graduates with the skills necessary to thrive in the tech industry. Additionally, Florida has made significant investments in technical schools and coding bootcamps, offering students hands-on experience in tech-related fields. This ensures that companies have access to a diverse talent pool with both theoretical knowledge and practical skills.
Furthermore, the state's affordable cost of living and high quality of life make it an attractive destination for professionals. Unlike more expensive tech hubs, such as Silicon Valley or New York, Florida offers a more affordable lifestyle without sacrificing career opportunities. This has led to a migration of tech talent from other states, further strengthening Florida's tech workforce.
The Rise of Tech Innovation Clusters
As more tech companies relocate to Florida, the state is seeing the development of innovation clusters. Cities like Miami, Orlando, and Tampa have become magnets for tech startups, venture capital firms, and incubators. Miami, in particular, has earned the nickname 'Silicon Beach,' as it attracts tech entrepreneurs and investors looking for a more affordable and livable alternative to Silicon Valley.
Orlando has become a hub for simulation technology and video game development, thanks to the presence of companies like EA Sports and the University of Central Florida's world-renowned simulation and training program. Tampa is home to a growing cybersecurity industry, with companies like ReliaQuest and the University of South Florida's cybersecurity program driving innovation in the field.
These tech clusters create a network effect, where the presence of tech companies attracts more tech companies, investors, and talent. This virtuous cycle leads to further innovation, job creation, and economic growth. It also creates a supportive ecosystem where entrepreneurs can access funding, mentorship, and resources necessary to scale their businesses.
Government Support and Incentives for Tech Growth
Florida's state government has played an active role in fostering a business-friendly environment that supports tech growth. The government offers a variety of grants, tax credits, and incentives aimed specifically at tech companies. Programs like the Qualified Target Industry Tax Refund (QTI) provide financial incentives for companies that create high-wage jobs in the state.
In addition to financial incentives, Florida's government has launched initiatives to foster innovation and entrepreneurship. The Florida Innovation Hub and various tech incubators across the state offer resources for startups, including office space, mentorship, and networking opportunities. These initiatives are designed to support the growth of new companies and ensure that Florida remains competitive in attracting tech talent and businesses.
Furthermore, Florida's government has actively worked to attract tech giants and established companies to the state. Major players like Amazon, Microsoft, and Google have established significant operations in Florida, further enhancing the state's reputation as a tech-friendly location.
Conclusion
Florida's business-friendly environment has transformed it into one of the fastest-growing tech hubs in the United States. The state's favorable tax policies, regulatory framework, and investment in infrastructure create an ideal environment for tech companies to thrive. Additionally, its growing talent pool and strategic location provide further advantages for companies with global ambitions.
As tech companies continue to migrate to Florida, the state is poised to become a major player in the tech industry. With its attractive lifestyle, competitive business environment, and supportive government policies, Florida offers a unique proposition for tech companies seeking to innovate, grow, and compete in the global marketplace. The Sunshine State is no longer just a destination for tourists; it is rapidly becoming a destination for tech innovation.
